description: Mid-17th century. Equivalent to name +â€Ž sake. From the phrase "for (one's) name's sake", first found in Bible translations as a rendering of a Hebrew idiom meaning "to protect one's reputation" or possibly "vouched for by one's reputation." A familiar example is in Psalm 23:3, "he leadeth me in the paths of righteousness for his name's sake" (King James Bible, 1604).

entries.meaning: (originally) One who is named after another or for whom another is named.
(by extension) A ship or a building that is named after someone or something.
A person with the same name as another.

verbs.description: namesake (third-person singular simple present namesakes, present participle namesaking, simple past and past participle namesaked)
